close_symbols: struct (c->rq) (fields: num_cr_sp_replaced, skipped_broken_lines, method, field_lines, header_size, headers_received_tail, version)
connection state constants (MHD_CONNECTION_FOOTERS_RECEIVING, MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_HEADERS_RECEIVING, MHD_CONNECTION_FULL_REQ_RECEIVED, MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_RECEIVED, MHD_CONNECTION_FOOTERS_RECEIVED)
explanation:
To determine whether get_req_headers violates MISRA's 'for loop shall be well-formed' rule you must (a) inspect every for statement appearing in the function itself and (b) inspect the behaviour of any functions called from inside any for statement bodies (MISRA's definition of the loop body includes called functions). Although get_req_headers contains no for loops itself, the analysis still requires the following symbols so the reviewer can (1) detect any for loops in callees that would be executed as part of get_req_headers and (2) check whether those for loops (or any macros they expand to) modify objects that would violate the rule relative to any loop counters or loop-control flags used in the containing for loops.

Why each symbol is required:
- get_req_header: Called inside the do/while loop; must be inspected for any for statements or side effects that would interact with surrounding loop counters/flags.
- MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_: Called when storing header/footer; may contain for loops or modify connection fields used elsewhere — its body must be checked.
- MHD_connection_alloc_memory_: Callee of the above; included because deeper callees can contain for loops or modify objects used by surrounding loops.
- MHD_DLOG: Logging macro/function invoked from this function and from callees; may be a macro that expands to code containing loops — inspect for loops/side effects.
- handle_req_headers_no_space: Called when allocation fails; must be inspected for for loops that could be executed in context of get_req_headers.
- handle_req_footers_no_space: Same reason as above for footers.
- reset_rq_header_processing_state: Called between header reads; include to rule out loops or modifications to connection state/fields used by potential for loops.
- transmit_error_response_len: Used by the no-space handlers; include to inspect its body for for loops/side effects.
- get_no_space_err_status_code: Used by the no-space handler; include for completeness if it contains loops or side effects.
- mhd_assert (macro): Many assertions are present; macros can expand to complex code — include to ensure no hidden for loops/side effects.
- memmove: Standard library call used to shift buffer contents; while libc implementations may contain loops, MISRA analysis usually requires awareness of side-effecting calls; include to note its presence (but its internal implementation is typically out of project scope).
- strlen: Used to assert lengths; include to note its invocation in assertions (possible loop in library implementation).

Data types and fields (structs, enums, constants):
- struct MHD_Connection and the listed fields (state, daemon, stop_with_error, discard_request, read_buffer, read_buffer_size, read_buffer_offset, rq): The rule forbids modification of loop counters or use of objects modified in the loop body; we must know which connection fields are read/modified in get_req_headers and in callees to detect forbidden uses in any for loops.
- struct c->rq subfields (num_cr_sp_replaced, skipped_broken_lines, method, field_lines, header_size, headers_received_tail, version) and the nested types (field_lines.start/size, headers_received_tail.value/value_size): These are referenced/modified in this function; if any for loops in this function or callees use them as loop counters or if callees modify them, that could contravene the rule.
- struct _MHD_str_w_len (str,len): Local header name/value structures used across calls — required to see whether any for loops modify these objects or use them as counters.
- enum MHD_HdrLineReadRes_ values: Used to control loop flow; include to understand control-flow and potential loop counters/flags.
- connection state constants (MHD_CONNECTION_...): State is tested and modified; if any for loop uses state as a loop counter or if callees modify state within loop bodies, that must be checked.
- MHD_HEADER_KIND, MHD_FOOTER_KIND, MHD_NO, MHD_BUF_INC_SIZE, HTTP_VER_LEN: Constants used in allocation/branching and buffer arithmetic — include to understand any buffer-shift operations or conditional code that could be part of loop logic or cause modification of objects referenced by a for loop.

In short: to certify compliance you must inspect the bodies (definitions) of the listed functions/macros and the definitions/layout/fields of the listed structs/enums/constants so you can (1) find all for statements reachable from get_req_headers and (2) verify that their first/second/third clauses and any called functions do not modify loop counters or other forbidden objects per MISRA. Provide the source (function bodies and type definitions) for these symbols to the next analyst.
